official-title.#text:
To amend the Communications Act of 1934 to limit the authority of the Federal Communications
			 Commission over providers of broadband Internet access service.

sponsor.#tail: introduced the following bill; which was referred to the

text.#text:
The Internet is a powerful engine for economic growth that has remained open, free, and accessible
			 without government regulation since its entrance into the public sphere.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
was designed for the monopoly telephone system in 1934
			 and has its origins in 19th century shipping regulations.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Title II of the Communications Act of 1934

text.#text:
Imposing the obligations and requirements of title II of such Act on broadband Internet access
			 service would severely harm broadband investment and create myriad
			 negative unintended consequences.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
has consistently taken actions that classify broadband
			 Internet access service, even in different forms, as an information
			 service. Such actions include the following:

text.#text:
In 1998, Chairman Bill Kennard issued a Report to Congress finding that Internet access is an
			 information service with a telecommunications component.

In 2002, the Commission issued a Declaratory Ruling (17 FCC Rcd 4798) classifying cable modem
			 broadband Internet access service as an information service. In the 2005
			 case of National Cable & Telecommunications Association v. Brand X Internet Services (545 U.S. 967), the Supreme Court of
			 the United States affirmed this determination that such service is not a
			 common carrier service and is appropriately classified as an information
			 service.

In 2005, the Commission issued a Report and Order (20 FCC Rcd 14853) affirming the classification
			 of wireline broadband Internet access service as an information service.

In 2007, the Commission issued a Declaratory Ruling (22 FCC Rcd 5901) affirming the classification
			 of wireless broadband Internet access service as an information service.

These Commission rulings unleashed tens of billions of dollars of investment in the Nation’s
			 broadband networks, investment that would not have been made if broadband
			 services were subject to common carrier requirements.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Section 3 of the Communications Act of 1934

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: is amended by adding at the end the following:

quote.#text:
Such term does not include a provider of an information service or of advanced telecommunications
			 capability (as defined in

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
) when engaged in the provision of such service or
			 capability.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
section 706 of the Telecommunications Act of
			 1996

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: is amended to read as follows:

continuation-text.#text:
Such term includes broadband Internet access service. A provider of an information service may not
			 be treated as a telecommunications carrier under this Act when engaged in
			 the provision of an information service, and may not be required to offer
			 such service or any component of such service as a telecommunications
			 service.

quote.#tail:
means the offering of a capability for generating, acquiring, storing, transforming, processing,
			 retrieving, utilizing, or making available information via
			 telecommunications, and includes electronic publishing, but does not
			 include—

text.#text:
any use of any such capability for the management, control, or operation of a telecommunications
			 system or the management of a telecommunications service.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: is amended by adding at the end the following:

quote.#text:
Such term does not include a provider of an information service or of advanced telecommunications
			 capability (as defined in

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
) when engaged in the provision of such service or
			 capability.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
section 706 of the Telecommunications Act of
			 1996

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: is amended by adding at the end the following:

quote.#text:
Such term does not include any service that is an information service, any component of an
			 information service, or advanced telecommunications capability (as defined
			 in

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: section 706 of the Telecommunications Act of 1996
Section 3 of the Communications Act of 1934

quote.#tail:
means a mass-market retail service by wire or radio that provides the capability to transmit data
			 to and receive data from all or substantially all Internet endpoints,
			 including any capabilities that are incidental to and enable the operation
			 of the communications service, but excluding dial-up Internet access
			 service. Broadband Internet access service is an information service, and
			 includes a service utilizing advanced telecommunications capability (as
			 defined in

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: section 706 of the Telecommunications Act of 1996
